nodes.name: Habituation
nodes.description: Reversible decrement of a response during repetitive stimulation, a form of non-associative learning.

nodes.name: Non-associative learning
nodes.description: A primitive form of learning that includes habituation and sensitization, not requiring association between stimuli.

nodes.name: HEK cells
nodes.description: Human embryonic kidney cells used as a non-neuronal model system.

nodes.name: Channelrhodopsin-2
nodes.description: An optogenetic actuator used to induce depolarization via photocurrent upon light stimulation.

nodes.name: Depolarization
nodes.description: The change in membrane potential towards a more positive value, induced by photocurrent in this study.

nodes.name: Potassium channels
nodes.description: Native ion channels in HEK cells that mediate the habituation phenotype.

nodes.name: Tetraethylammonium
nodes.description: A potassium channel blocker used to identify the role of native channels in habituation.

nodes.name: Optogenetics
nodes.description: Method using light to control cells expressing light-sensitive ion channels.

nodes.name: Patch clamp
nodes.description: Electrophysiological technique used to record membrane potential and currents in whole-cell configuration.

nodes.name: Membrane potential
nodes.description: The voltage difference across the cell membrane, monitored during stimulation.

nodes.name: Repetitive stimulation
nodes.description: The application of repeated stimuli (light pulses) which induces habituation.

nodes.name: Xenopus laevis
nodes.description: An ideal model system for investigating the mechanisms of pattern formation and regeneration.

nodes.name: mRNA Electroporation
nodes.description: A method for delivering mRNA and other nucleic acids using electrical pulses.

nodes.name: Pattern Formation
nodes.description: The developmental process by which cells acquire different identities in an ordered spatial arrangement.

nodes.name: Spatio-temporal Control
nodes.description: The ability to restrict gene expression to specific tissues at specific times.

nodes.name: Cleavage-stage Injection
nodes.description: Injection of mRNAs into embryos during early cleavage stages.

nodes.name: Poring Pulse
nodes.description: A high voltage, short duration electrical pulse designed to form pores in the plasma membrane.

nodes.name: Driving Pulse
nodes.description: A low voltage, longer duration electrical pulse designed to drive charged molecules into the cytosol.

nodes.name: Plasma Membrane
nodes.description: The biological membrane separating the interior of all cells from the outside environment.

nodes.name: mRNA
nodes.description: Messenger RNA used for gain-of-function experiments.

nodes.name: Morpholinos
nodes.description: Oligomers used for loss-of-function experiments.

nodes.name: MS222
nodes.description: Tricaine methanesulfonate, used as an anesthetic for embryos.

nodes.name: Electrical Resistance
nodes.description: The opposition to current flow in the electroporation circuit, used to determine pulse parameters.

nodes.name: Transfection Efficiency
nodes.description: The rate at which the target molecules are successfully introduced into the cells.

nodes.name: CUY21EDIT
nodes.description: A specific square wave electroporator pulse generator.

nodes.name: Planaria
nodes.description: Free-living bilaterian flatworms capable of regenerating complete organisms from small fragments.

nodes.name: Anatomical Homeostasis
nodes.description: The ability of an organism to maintain or restore a specific large-scale anatomical pattern despite injury or metabolic turnover.

nodes.name: Target Morphology
nodes.description: The specific anatomical pattern or setpoint that an organism strives to achieve during regeneration.

nodes.name: Bioelectricity
nodes.description: Electrical signaling mechanisms in non-neural tissues involving ion flows and voltage gradients used for pattern control.

nodes.name: Voltage Gradient
nodes.description: Spatial differences in transmembrane potential (Vmem) across a tissue.

nodes.name: Gap Junction
nodes.description: Channels that form cytosolic connections between cells, allowing the sharing of electrical and chemical states.

nodes.name: H+/K+-ATPase
nodes.description: An ion pump protein that generates electrical gradients involved in head-tail polarity decisions.

nodes.name: Innexin
nodes.description: Invertebrate gap junction proteins crucial for network function and signaling propagation.

nodes.name: 1-octanol
nodes.description: A gap junction blocking reagent used to perturb bioelectric connectivity.

nodes.name: SCH28080
nodes.description: An ion pump blocker used to modulate bioelectric circuits.

nodes.name: Double-headed Heteromorphosis
nodes.description: A regenerative outcome where a planarian develops heads at both anterior and posterior ends.

nodes.name: Cryptic Worm
nodes.description: Planaria with normal anatomy but altered bioelectric pattern memory, which regenerate incorrectly when injured.

nodes.name: Wnt Signaling
nodes.description: A molecular signaling pathway strongly implicated in posterior development in planaria.

nodes.name: Notum
nodes.description: A gene expressed at the anterior pole, involved in head development and inhibition of Wnt.

nodes.name: BETSE
nodes.description: Bio-Electric Tissue Simulation Engine; a modeling environment for simulating bioelectric dynamics in tissues.

nodes.name: Machine Learning
nodes.description: Computational approaches used to infer regulatory networks and models from functional data.

nodes.name: Serotonin
nodes.description: A neurotransmitter identified as having functional roles in determining anterior-posterior polarity.

nodes.name: Agarose Sectioning
nodes.description: A method of embedding embryos in low melting point agarose and slicing them with a vibratome for immunohistochemistry.

nodes.name: Immunohistochemistry
nodes.description: A technique used to characterize protein localization in tissues using antibodies.

nodes.name: Protein Localization
nodes.description: The process of determining where specific proteins are located within cells or tissues.

nodes.name: Whole-mount Immunohistochemistry
nodes.description: An alternative method to visualize surface and ectodermal expression, noted for limited internal penetration.

nodes.name: Glutaraldehyde
nodes.description: A fixative agent noted for causing autofluorescence in tissues.

nodes.name: Autofluorescence
nodes.description: Natural emission of light by biological structures, which can interfere with fluorescent imaging.

nodes.name: MEMFA
nodes.description: A fixative solution used to preserve embryos before sectioning.

nodes.name: Methanol
nodes.description: An organic solvent used for dehydration and rehydration of embryos.

nodes.name: Hydrogen Peroxide
nodes.description: A chemical used to quench endogenous peroxide activity.

nodes.name: Tyramide Signal Amplification
nodes.description: An enzymatic method to amplify positive signals, useful for low-abundance proteins.

nodes.name: Alkaline Phosphatase
nodes.description: An enzyme used as a label for secondary antibodies to produce a visible colored precipitate.

nodes.name: Horseradish Peroxidase
nodes.description: An enzyme used in immunohistochemistry for signal detection, often with tyramide amplification.

nodes.name: Vibratome
nodes.description: An instrument used to cut thick sections of agarose-embedded tissue.

nodes.name: Low Melting Point Agarose
nodes.description: The medium used to embed embryos for sectioning.

nodes.name: Scale-Free Cognition
nodes.description: A hypothesis suggesting that cognition is not binary but exists on a continuum and can occur at multiple levels of organization (cells, tissues, organisms).

nodes.name: Cognitive Light Cone
nodes.description: The spatio-temporal boundary of events that a system can measure, model, and try to affect, defining the scale of its cognition.

nodes.name: Homeostasis
nodes.description: The ability of a system to maintain internal stability; proposed as the 'atom' or primitive origin of cognitive goals.

nodes.name: Infotaxis
nodes.description: The drive to collect information from the environment to minimize surprise and optimize prediction.

nodes.name: Cancer
nodes.description: Described as a shrinking of the cognitive boundary where cells revert to unicellular goals due to isolation from the physiological network.

nodes.name: Multicellularity
nodes.description: The cooperation of single cells to form complex bodies, driven by the scaling of cognitive capacities.

nodes.name: Ion Channel
nodes.description: Proteins that gate the flow of ions across membranes, generating bioelectric signals.

nodes.name: Tunneling Nanotube
nodes.description: Axon-like structures connecting cells in a tissue, mechanistically presaging neural axons.

nodes.name: Automated Shapeshifting
nodes.description: The ability of a robot to automatically recover from unexpected damage by deforming its resting mechanical structure without changing its control policy.

nodes.name: Controller Readaptation
nodes.description: A method where a robot learns new ways to control its body when damaged, keeping the mechanical structure fixed.

nodes.name: Soft Robot
nodes.description: Machines constructed from compliant materials capable of deforming their structures and possessing theoretically infinite degrees of freedom.

nodes.name: Regeneration
nodes.description: The biological process of regrowing lost parts, organs, or function after injury, or the robotic analogue of recovering structure.

nodes.name: Morphological Computation
nodes.description: The idea that the body itself (structure and materials) performs computation, facilitating control and adaptation.

nodes.name: Salamander
nodes.description: An amphibian capable of regenerating whole limbs, eyes, tails, and organs.

nodes.name: Metamorphosis
nodes.description: A biological process involving drastic rearrangement of tissues and morphology, during which information/memory is retained.

nodes.name: Developmental Plasticity
nodes.description: The ability of an organism to alter its development or morphology in response to environmental conditions or injury.

nodes.name: Compositional Pattern-Producing Network
nodes.description: A neural network encoding used to map spatial coordinates to robot attributes (shape or control phase offsets).

nodes.name: Evolutionary Algorithm
nodes.description: An optimization algorithm used to search for deformations and control policies that result in function recovery.

nodes.name: Computational Control Circuitry
nodes.description: The information processing mechanisms within biological tissues that direct growth and morphogenesis.

nodes.name: Nervous System
nodes.description: The network of nerve cells and fibers that transmits nerve impulses, capable of regeneration in planaria.

nodes.name: Silicone
nodes.description: Elastomeric material used to construct the soft robotic voxels.

nodes.name: Hyperpolarization
nodes.description: An increase in the magnitude of the membrane potential, making it more negative.

nodes.name: Human Mesenchymal Stem Cell
nodes.description: Adult stem cells used as the model organism/cell source in this study.
aliases: human bone marrow mesenchymal stem cells

nodes.name: Osteoblast
nodes.description: Bone-forming cells derived from hMSCs.

nodes.name: Adipocyte
nodes.description: Fat-storing cells derived from hMSCs.

nodes.name: Ouabain
nodes.description: A Na+/K+ ATPase inhibitor used to induce depolarization.

nodes.name: High Extracellular Potassium
nodes.description: Method of depolarizing cells by elevating extracellular K+ concentration (40 or 80 mM).

nodes.name: Transdifferentiation
nodes.description: The conversion of a cell from one differentiated lineage to another (e.g., osteoblast to adipocyte).

nodes.name: Dedifferentiation
nodes.description: The regression of a specialized cell to a simpler, more stem-like state.

nodes.name: IBSP
nodes.description: Bone sialoprotein, a marker for osteogenic differentiation.

nodes.name: PPARG
nodes.description: Peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor gamma, a marker for adipogenic differentiation.

nodes.name: LPL
nodes.description: Lipoprotein lipase, a marker for adipogenic differentiation.

nodes.name: Rho Signaling Pathway
nodes.description: A signaling pathway involved in cell structure and adhesion, identified in depolarized cells.

nodes.name: Stemness Markers
nodes.description: Genes associated with the stem state (e.g., BDNF, ITGA11, NEK7).

nodes.name: Innate Immunity
nodes.description: The first line of defense against pathogens, involving myeloid cells and inflammatory responses.

nodes.name: E. coli UTI89
nodes.description: A uropathogenic strain of Escherichia coli used to infect the embryos.

nodes.name: Dopamine
nodes.description: A neurotransmitter identified as a key signaling molecule in the brain-immune crosstalk.

nodes.name: Macrophage Migration
nodes.description: The movement of macrophages to sites of infection or injury.

nodes.name: Apoptosis
nodes.description: Programmed cell death, measured by Cleaved Caspase-3 levels.

nodes.name: Brain Removal
nodes.description: Surgical removal of the brain at stage 25 to study brain-dependent events.

nodes.name: SCH-23390
nodes.description: A specific D1 dopamine receptor antagonist used in pharmacological assays.

nodes.name: mmp7
nodes.description: Matrix metalloproteinase-7, a gene marker used to identify embryonic macrophages.

nodes.name: spib-a
nodes.description: A transcription factor marker for primitive myeloid cell lineage.

nodes.name: Cleaved Caspase-3
nodes.description: A marker used to detect activated apoptosis in the embryos.

nodes.name: Peripheral Neural Network
nodes.description: The network of nerves in the periphery, which becomes aberrant/ectopic in brainless embryos.

nodes.name: Host-Pathogen Response Index
nodes.description: A metric combining survival rates and pathogen load to assess tolerance and susceptibility.

nodes.name: Dj-Inx-5
nodes.description: A specific innexin gene in Dugesia japonica expressed in the CNS and sub-epithelial cells.

nodes.name: Dj-Inx-12
nodes.description: A specific innexin gene in Dugesia japonica involved in polarity determination.

nodes.name: Dj-Inx-13
nodes.description: A specific innexin gene in Dugesia japonica involved in polarity determination.

nodes.name: Ventral Nerve Cord
nodes.description: Longitudinal nerve cords running along the A/P axis of the planarian.

nodes.name: Anterior-Posterior Polarity
nodes.description: The establishment of head-to-tail axis orientation during regeneration.

nodes.name: Bipolar Head Regeneration
nodes.description: The formation of heads at both anterior and posterior ends of a regenerating fragment.

nodes.name: Neoblast
nodes.description: Adult somatic stem cells in planarians responsible for regeneration.

nodes.name: Blastema
nodes.description: A mass of undifferentiated cells capable of growth and regeneration into organs or body parts.

nodes.name: RNA Interference
nodes.description: A biological process in which RNA molecules inhibit gene expression or translation.

nodes.name: Long-range Signaling
nodes.description: Communication between distant parts of the organism to coordinate morphogenesis.

nodes.name: Left-Right Patterning
nodes.description: The process of morphogenesis that establishes the left-right axis and asymmetry in embryos.
aliases: left-right patterning of the heart and viscera

nodes.name: Situs Inversus
nodes.description: A condition where the arrangement of internal organs is a mirror image of normal anatomy.

nodes.name: Nodal
nodes.description: A universally-conserved Left determinant gene involved in the asymmetric signaling cascade.

nodes.name: Cilia
nodes.description: Microscopic hair-like structures on cells, often implicated in initiating LR patterning via fluid flow.

nodes.name: Sonic Hedgehog
nodes.description: A signaling protein expressed on the left side of the node in chick embryos.

nodes.name: Midline
nodes.description: The reflection line across which overall symmetry is preserved and the LR axis is defined.

nodes.name: Vg1
nodes.description: A signaling molecule whose overexpression or perturbation affects laterality.

nodes.name: Retinoic Acid
nodes.description: A signaling molecule that shields somites from asymmetric cues.

nodes.name: iv mutant
nodes.description: A spontaneous mouse mutant exhibiting 50% situs inversus and 50% situs solitus.

nodes.name: Ectopic Eye
nodes.description: An eye primordium transplanted to a non-native location (e.g., the tail) of the host organism.

nodes.name: Hyperinnervation
nodes.description: A phenotype characterized by drastic extension of axons throughout the body of the host.

nodes.name: Ivermectin
nodes.description: A chloride channel activator that depolarizes cells expressing glutamate/glycine-gated chloride channels.

nodes.name: GlyCl
nodes.description: Glycine-gated chloride channel, the target of ivermectin.

nodes.name: Kir4.1
nodes.description: A hyperpolarizing potassium channel used to experimentally manipulate membrane potential.

nodes.name: Fluoxetine
nodes.description: A selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) that blocks the 5-HT transporter (SERT).

nodes.name: Lindane
nodes.description: A chemical inhibitor of gap junction channels.

nodes.name: H7 Construct
nodes.description: A dominant negative gap junction construct (3243H7) that reduces or abolishes native gap junction communication.

nodes.name: 5-HT Receptor 1
nodes.description: A family of serotonin receptors implicated in the hyperinnervation signaling pathway.

nodes.name: 5-HT Receptor 2
nodes.description: A family of serotonin receptors implicated in the hyperinnervation signaling pathway.

nodes.name: SERT
nodes.description: The serotonin transporter protein responsible for moving 5-HT across membranes.

nodes.name: Axon Guidance
nodes.description: The process by which neurons send out axons to reach correct targets.

nodes.name: Sholl Analysis
nodes.description: A quantitative method used to measure the extent and branching of innervation.

nodes.name: Histone Deacetylase
nodes.description: Enzyme that removes acetyl groups from histones, leading to chromatin compaction and gene repression.

nodes.name: Mad3
nodes.description: A Max-interacting transcriptional repressor that recruits HDAC complexes and binds serotonin.

nodes.name: Sodium Butyrate
nodes.description: A pharmacological inhibitor of HDAC activity.

nodes.name: H3K4me2
nodes.description: Dimethylation of histone H3 at lysine 4, an epigenetic marker associated with chromatin state.

nodes.name: Chromatin Immunoprecipitation
nodes.description: Method used to determine epigenetic markers on specific gene regions.

nodes.name: Free Energy Principle
nodes.description: A scale-free formal framework stating that self-organizing systems minimize variational free energy to maintain their identifiability.

nodes.name: Markov Blanket
nodes.description: A boundary that separates a system's internal states from the states of its environment.

nodes.name: Variational Free Energy
nodes.description: An information-theoretic quantity that serves as an upper bound on Bayesian surprisal; systems minimize this to maintain homeostasis.

nodes.name: Generative Model
nodes.description: An internal model used by a system to generate predictions about the consequences of its actions on its Markov blanket.

nodes.name: Mutual Inhibition
nodes.description: A mechanism where competing networks or pathways inhibit each other, enabling context-specific selection of action or perception.

nodes.name: Gene Regulatory Network
nodes.description: Networks of gene interactions that control metabolic and morphological processes.

nodes.name: Bioelectric Pattern Memory
nodes.description: Stored bioelectric states that guide morphogenesis and regeneration, capable of being modified to produce alternative morphologies.

nodes.name: Tensor Network
nodes.description: A mathematical factorization of high-dimensional tensors used to represent control flow systems and quantum states.

nodes.name: Quantum Reference Frame
nodes.description: A framework for describing physical systems where components of the generative model are considered distinct frames of reference.

nodes.name: Cell Membrane
nodes.description: The biological structure that acts as the Markov blanket for a cell.

nodes.name: Escherichia coli
nodes.description: A bacterium used as an example of basal active inference and metabolic control.

nodes.name: Allostasis
nodes.description: The process of achieving stability through change; maintaining the structural and functional integrity of a system.

nodes.name: Topological Quantum Field Theory
nodes.description: A quantum field theory that computes topological invariants, used here to map sequential measurements and control flow.

nodes.name: Zolmitriptan
nodes.description: A 5-HT 1B/D receptor agonist drug approved for human use, used here to induce innervation.

nodes.name: 5-HT 1B/D receptor
nodes.description: A specific subtype of serotonin receptor whose activation promotes neurite outgrowth and innervation.

nodes.name: Innervation
nodes.description: The process of nerves growing into a tissue; in this context, the extension of axons from the graft into the host.

nodes.name: Visual learning
nodes.description: The ability of the organism to change behavior based on visual stimuli, such as color discrimination.

nodes.name: Pattern recognition
nodes.description: A higher-order visual function involving the ability to resolve movement and directionality of external objects.

nodes.name: Spinal cord
nodes.description: Part of the central nervous system; hypothesized to be the integration point for ectopic eye signals in this study.

nodes.name: Retinal ganglion cell
nodes.description: Neurons located near the inner surface of the retina whose axons form the optic nerve.

nodes.name: Lateral line
nodes.description: A system of sense organs found in aquatic vertebrates, used to detect movement and vibration.

nodes.name: tdTomato
nodes.description: A fluorescent protein used as a marker to visualize donor tissue and innervation.

nodes.name: Automated visual assay
nodes.description: A custom apparatus using motion tracking and LED illumination to train and test tadpoles on visual tasks.

nodes.name: Kir2.1
nodes.description: A potassium channel gene implicated in patterning and craniofacial morphogenesis.

nodes.name: Pax6
nodes.description: A gene essential for eye development, regulated by voltage states.

nodes.name: SLC5A8
nodes.description: A sodium-coupled monocarboxylate transporter that links voltage changes to HDAC activity.

nodes.name: Butyrate
nodes.description: A small molecule regulator of histone deacetylases, transported by SLC5A8.

nodes.name: Voltage Reporter Dyes
nodes.description: Fluorescent dyes used to detect Vmem distributions non-invasively.

nodes.name: Frizzled
nodes.description: A gene involved in craniofacial morphogenesis whose expression is preceded by Vmem gradients.

nodes.name: PTEN
nodes.description: A phosphatase involved in the pathway required for cells to sense endogenous electric fields.

nodes.name: Sodium Flux
nodes.description: Movement of sodium ions, manipulation of which can initiate regeneration.

nodes.name: Glibenclamide
nodes.description: A pharmacological agent that acts as an antagonist of the inward rectifying, ATP-sensitive K+ channel (Kir 6.x).

nodes.name: Monensin
nodes.description: An ionophore with selectivity for the Na+ ion used to modulate electrophysiology.

nodes.name: Barium Chloride
nodes.description: A general K+ channel blocker used to modulate electrophysiology.

nodes.name: Kir6.x Channel
nodes.description: Inward rectifying, ATP-sensitive potassium channel.

nodes.name: Sodium Ion
nodes.description: Positively charged ion involved in bioelectric signaling.

nodes.name: Mineralization
nodes.description: The deposition of mineral (calcium) in the bone matrix, a late-stage osteogenic marker.

nodes.name: DiSBAC
nodes.description: Bis-(1,3-diethylthiobarbituric acid)trimethine oxonol, an anionic voltage-sensitive fluorescent dye.

nodes.name: Silk Fibroin Scaffold
nodes.description: Porous 3D scaffolds made from Bombyx mori silk used to culture bone tissue.

nodes.name: Runx2
nodes.description: Runt-related transcription factor 2, an early marker of osteogenic differentiation.

nodes.name: Col1
nodes.description: Collagen I alpha 1, a marker of bone matrix formation.

nodes.name: Electrophoresis
nodes.description: The redistribution of charged molecules under the influence of an endogenous electric field created by ion channel and pump activity.

nodes.name: Morphogen Gradient
nodes.description: A spatio-temporal concentration gradient of signaling molecules that establishes large-scale patterns during embryogenesis.

nodes.name: Particle Tracking Simulation
nodes.description: A stochastic computer model used to simulate the trajectories of individual morphogen particles.

nodes.name: Langevin's Equation
nodes.description: A stochastic differential equation describing the acceleration of a particle with Brownian motion in viscous fluid under electric potential.

nodes.name: Blastomere
nodes.description: Early embryonic cells in the Xenopus embryo that are coupled by gap junctions.

nodes.name: Brownian Motion
nodes.description: The random motion of particles suspended in a fluid, contributing to the stochastic nature of morphogen movement.

nodes.name: Par6
nodes.description: An apical-basal polarity protein involved in establishing cell polarity and tight junctions.

nodes.name: aPKC
nodes.description: Atypical Protein Kinase C, forms a complex with Par6 to establish apical-basal polarity.

nodes.name: Vangl2
nodes.description: A Planar Cell Polarity (PCP) protein, homolog of Drosophila Van Gogh.

nodes.name: Apical-Basal Polarity
nodes.description: The asymmetry of cell structure and function along the apical-basal axis.

nodes.name: Planar Cell Polarity
nodes.description: The coordinated polarization of cells within the plane of a tissue layer.

nodes.name: Tight Junction
nodes.description: Cell junctions that maintain epithelial integrity and are required for physiological gradients.

nodes.name: Gastrocoel Roof Plate
nodes.description: The ciliated structure in Xenopus embryos analogous to the mouse node, involved in LR patterning.

nodes.name: Big Brother Effect
nodes.description: The instruction of a secondary (induced) organizer's laterality by the primary organizer.

nodes.name: CDC42
nodes.description: A Rho GTPase involved in establishing cell polarity.

nodes.name: RSG1
nodes.description: Rem/Rab-Similar GTPase 1, a PCP effector gene.

nodes.name: Disheveled
nodes.description: A protein involved in both canonical Wnt and PCP signaling pathways.

nodes.name: XSiamois
nodes.description: A transcription factor used to induce secondary organizers (twins).

nodes.name: Anticonvulsant
nodes.description: Drugs used to suppress excessive firing of neurons to prevent seizures.

nodes.name: Valproate
nodes.description: A traditional anticonvulsant drug associated with high risk of malformations.

nodes.name: Lamotrigine
nodes.description: A newer anticonvulsant drug with lower overall malformation risk but potential link to oral clefts.

nodes.name: Voltage-sensitive Sodium Channel
nodes.description: Ion channels that allow sodium influx; blockage inhibits action potential firing.

nodes.name: Neural Tube Defect
nodes.description: A major congenital malformation involving the brain and spine.

nodes.name: Oral Cleft
nodes.description: A congenital malformation of the mouth/lip.

nodes.name: Cell Division
nodes.description: The process by which a parent cell divides into two or more daughter cells.

nodes.name: Differentiation
nodes.description: The process where a cell changes from one cell type to another.

nodes.name: T-type Calcium Channel
nodes.description: Low-voltage activated calcium channels.

nodes.name: Neuron
nodes.description: Specialized cells of the nervous system optimized for rapid communication and control of muscle motion.

nodes.name: Microglia
nodes.description: The primary innate immune cells in the central nervous system, playing roles in development, homeostasis, and disease.

nodes.name: Cytokine
nodes.description: Signaling molecules produced by immune cells that can regulate neuronal function and behavior.

nodes.name: Self-organization
nodes.description: The spontaneous emergence of spatio-temporal order or pattern-formation processes in biological systems.

nodes.name: Astrocyte
nodes.description: Non-neuronal brain cells that contribute to blood-brain barrier, synaptogenesis, and ion homeostasis.

nodes.name: Proton Flux
nodes.description: The flow of H+ ions across the plasma membrane, specifically efflux from the cell.

nodes.name: pH
nodes.description: The measure of acidity or alkalinity in the cytoplasm or extracellular environment.

nodes.name: Concanamycin
nodes.description: A potent and highly-specific pharmacological inhibitor of V-ATPase.

nodes.name: Kupffer's Vesicle
nodes.description: A ciliated organ in zebrafish embryos involved in establishing left-right asymmetry.

nodes.name: SERIS
nodes.description: Self referencing ion selective probe used to measure net efflux of protons.

nodes.name: DiBAC4(3)
nodes.description: A membrane voltage sensitive fluorescent dye.

nodes.name: Zebrafish
nodes.description: Fish model organism (Danio rerio).

nodes.name: PMA1.2
nodes.description: A yeast plasma-membrane H+ pump used to induce ectopic H+ flux.

nodes.name: NHE3
nodes.description: An electroneutral Na+/H+ exchanger used to manipulate pH without changing voltage.

nodes.name: Physarum polycephalum
nodes.description: A macroscopic multinucleate single celled slime mould organism capable of complex network formation and computation.

nodes.name: Protoplasmic tube

nodes.name: LALF stimulation

nodes.name: HAHF stimulation
nodes.description: High Amplitude High Frequency voltage stimulation (2.5 V peak-to-peak at 1000 Hz) applied to the organism.

nodes.name: Sentience
nodes.description: The capacity for feeling, suffering, or subjective experience, often associated with moral concern.

nodes.name: Bioengineering
nodes.description: The application of engineering principles to biological systems, creating novel agents and cyborgs.

nodes.name: Electrically Active Cell
nodes.description: Cells capable of generating and transmitting electrical signals, proposed as a more general substrate for sentience than neurons.

nodes.name: Hybrot
nodes.description: Cultured brains integrated with robotic bodies.

nodes.name: Oocyte

nodes.name: Somatic Tissue
nodes.description: Body tissues other than the germline, capable of minimal cognition.

nodes.name: Turing Test
nodes.description: A test of a machine's ability to exhibit intelligent behavior equivalent to, or indistinguishable from, that of a human, relying on verbal reports.

nodes.name: Morphogenetic Agent
nodes.description: Non-neural systems capable of morphogenesis and meeting criteria for sentience.

nodes.name: Analgesia

nodes.name: CC2-DMPE

nodes.name: Cell-Cell Communication

nodes.name: Fluorescence Microscopy
nodes.description: Imaging technique used to visualize the fluorescent reporters.

nodes.name: HCN2 Channel
nodes.description: Hyperpolarization-activated Cyclic nucleotide-gated channel 2, a voltage-gated ion channel.

nodes.name: Nicotine

nodes.name: Xbf1

nodes.name: Gabapentin
nodes.description: An FDA-approved small-molecule drug and ion channel activator used to induce repair.

nodes.name: Brain Patterning

nodes.name: Long-Range Bioelectric Signaling

nodes.name: Neural Plate

nodes.name: KCNE1

nodes.name: Slug

nodes.name: Chromanol 293B
nodes.description: A specific pharmacological blocker of the KCNQ1 channel.

nodes.name: RL-3
nodes.description: A pharmacological opener/activator of the KCNQ1 channel.

nodes.name: Hyperproliferation
nodes.description: Excessive cell division, observed in melanocytes following KCNE1 misexpression.

nodes.name: Invasiveness
nodes.description: The ability of cells to spread into tissues where they are not normally found.

nodes.name: Thioridazine
nodes.description: A dopamine receptor antagonist used to treat schizophrenia, used here to test predictions about sensory precision in development.

nodes.name: Sensory precision
nodes.description: A parameter in active inference encoding the confidence or weight assigned to incoming sensory information versus prior beliefs.

nodes.name: Bioelectrical pattern
nodes.description: Spatially distributed electrical states in tissue that serve as sensory information for cells during morphogenesis.

nodes.name: Schizophrenia
nodes.description: A psychopathological condition modeled as a disorder of inference (aberrant precision), used as a parallel for developmental defects.

nodes.name: Autism
nodes.description: A neurodevelopmental condition linked to aberrant precision (high sensory precision), used as a parallel for developmental defects.

nodes.name: Sensory attenuation
nodes.description: The transient suspension of attention to sensory consequences of action, necessary for movement and morphogenesis.

nodes.name: Collective intelligence
nodes.description: Emergent problem-solving capacity of groups of cells navigating anatomical morphospace.

nodes.name: Neurocristopathy
nodes.description: Developmental defects involving neural crest cells, drawn as a parallel to simulated defects caused by high sensory precision.

nodes.name: Intracellular Calcium Concentration
nodes.description: The level of Ca2+ ions inside the cell, which acts as a signaling mechanism.

nodes.name: DNA Methylation
nodes.description: An epigenetic mechanism involving the addition of methyl groups to the DNA molecule, often modifying gene expression.

nodes.name: Tumor Microenvironment
nodes.description: The environment surrounding a tumor, including signaling molecules and physical conditions that influence tumor behavior.

nodes.name: Hyperpolarizing Ion Channel Gene
nodes.description: Genes encoding ion channels that normally function to hyperpolarize the cell membrane.

nodes.name: KI67
nodes.description: A protein marker strictly associated with cell proliferation.

nodes.name: DNA Methyltransferase
nodes.description: Enzymes that catalyze the transfer of methyl groups to DNA.

nodes.name: MDA-MB-231
nodes.description: A human breast cancer cell line used for in-vitro and xenograft experiments.

nodes.name: Fluo3-AM
nodes.description: A fluorescent dye used to measure intracellular calcium concentration.

nodes.name: Xenograft
nodes.description: Transplantation of living cells, tissues or organs from one species to another, used here to grow human tumors in mice.

nodes.name: Sertraline
nodes.description: A selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) antidepressant medication.

nodes.name: Drosophila melanogaster
nodes.description: A model organism used to study developmental processes and mechanisms of relevance to human medicine.

nodes.name: DNA Double-Strand Break
nodes.description: A form of DNA damage where both strands of the DNA double helix are severed.

nodes.name: Oxidative Stress
nodes.description: An imbalance between free radicals and antioxidants, suggested as the mechanism for sertraline toxicity.

nodes.name: Ascorbic Acid
nodes.description: An antioxidant that can ameliorate sertraline-induced genotoxicity.

nodes.name: gamma-H2Av
nodes.description: A phosphorylated histone variant used as a marker for DNA double-strand breaks in Drosophila.

nodes.name: Death Caspase-1
nodes.description: An effector caspase that promotes degradation of target proteins during apoptosis, used as a marker for cell death.

nodes.name: Wing Imaginal Disc
nodes.description: Larval tissues containing rapidly dividing diploid cells that become adult wings.

nodes.name: Reactive Oxygen Species
nodes.description: Chemically reactive chemical species containing oxygen, such as superoxide radicals.

nodes.name: Dihydroethidium
nodes.description: A compound used to stain for superoxide radicals.

nodes.name: BHQ-O-5HT
nodes.description: A caged form of serotonin with a phenolic ether linkage that releases 5-HT upon exposure to light.

nodes.name: BHQ-N-5HT
nodes.description: A caged form of serotonin with a carbamate linker, found to be less effective for rapid release than the O-version.

nodes.name: Mus musculus
nodes.description: Mouse model organism from which dorsal root ganglia neurons were harvested.

nodes.name: Dorsal Root Ganglia
nodes.description: A cluster of neurons in a dorsal root of a spinal nerve, containing cell bodies of sensory neurons.

nodes.name: Trigeminal Ganglion
nodes.description: A sensory ganglion of the trigeminal nerve, monitored for electrical activity in zebrafish.

nodes.name: 5-HT3 Receptor
nodes.description: A ligand-gated ion channel receptor for serotonin that mediates fast synaptic transmission.

nodes.name: Photolysis
nodes.description: The decomposition or separation of molecules by the action of light, used here to uncage serotonin.

nodes.name: Two-Photon Excitation
nodes.description: A fluorescence imaging technique that allows for localization of release to sub-cellular levels using 740-nm light.

nodes.name: Stage 5
nodes.description: The 32-cell stage of Xenopus development, identified as a critical window for serotonin-mediated LR patterning.

nodes.name: Long-Distance Signal
nodes.description: Signaling mechanism originating in undisturbed tissue far from the amputation plane that regulates regeneration.

nodes.name: Femtosecond Laser Ablation
nodes.description: Use of ultrafast Ti:sapphire lasers to selectively destroy specific cell populations with high spatial resolution.

nodes.name: Geometric Morphometrics
nodes.description: Quantitative analysis of shape using landmark coordinates and multivariate statistics to detect morphological differences.

nodes.name: Positional Information
nodes.description: Information encoded along the AP axis that guides the growth and patterning of the regenerate.

nodes.name: Reissner's Fiber
nodes.description: A continuously renewing strand of proteins in the central canal of the spinal cord, proposed as a potential information conduit.

nodes.name: H+ Flux
nodes.description: Ion flux associated with tail regeneration, previously explored by the authors.

nodes.name: Notch signaling
nodes.description: A signaling pathway that regulates cell differentiation, tissue homeostasis, and neural stem cell maintenance.

nodes.name: YCHE78
nodes.description: A dominant-negative, truncated version of the V1e1 subunit of the v-ATPase complex used to inhibit v-ATPase activity.

nodes.name: Neural Stem Cell
nodes.description: Self-renewing multipotent cells in the developing cortex that generate neurons and glia.

nodes.name: Basal Progenitor
nodes.description: Committed neurogenic progenitors that migrate toward the basal boundary of the VZ.

nodes.name: Endosome Acidification
nodes.description: The lowering of pH within endosomes, mediated by proton pumps like v-ATPase.

nodes.name: Gamma-secretase
nodes.description: An enzyme complex responsible for the proteolytic cleavage of Notch.

nodes.name: Notch Intracellular Domain
nodes.description: The cytoplasmic, active domain of Notch released after cleavage.

nodes.name: Constitutively Active Notch
nodes.description: A transmembrane, gamma-secretase-dependent form of active Notch.

nodes.name: Cerebral Cortex
nodes.description: The region of the brain where neural stem cell differentiation was studied.

nodes.name: Hes5
nodes.description: A Notch target gene used as a reporter for endogenous Notch signaling.

nodes.name: Tbr2
nodes.description: A marker protein for basal progenitors.

nodes.name: In utero electroporation
nodes.description: A technique used to acutely and tissue-specifically manipulate genes in neural stem cells of the mouse brain.

nodes.name: Reality Gap
nodes.description: The discrepancy between the behavior of a robot in simulation and its behavior in the physical world.

nodes.name: Voxelyze
nodes.description: A soft-body physics engine used to simulate robots composed of actuating and/or passive, elastic voxels.

nodes.name: Pneumatic Actuation
nodes.description: A method of actuation using air pressure to cause volumetric changes in voxels.

nodes.name: Silicone Voxel
nodes.description: The modular building block of the physical soft robots, capable of being passive or active.

nodes.name: Locomotion
nodes.description: Movement or travel from one place to another, used as a metric for robot fitness.

nodes.name: Coulomb Friction
nodes.description: A model of friction assumed to be proportional to the normal force and independent of contact area, found to be insufficient for soft robot simulation.

nodes.name: Interfacial Shear Strength
nodes.description: A property governed by adhesion or mechanical interlocking between contacting surfaces that influences friction.

nodes.name: Functional Plasticity
nodes.description: The ability of biological systems to adapt function during development and regeneration.

nodes.name: Cognition
nodes.description: Mental processes including intelligence, decision-making, and learning, which can be realized in diverse systems.

nodes.name: Multiple Realizability
nodes.description: The philosophical and scientific concept that a function (like cognition) can be implemented by many different physical mechanisms or substrates.

nodes.name: Non-neural Tissue
nodes.description: Biological tissues not composed of neurons that may still exhibit cognitive potentials or information processing.

nodes.name: Action Potential
nodes.description: A rapid rise and fall in voltage across a cellular membrane, a specific form of electrical signaling.

nodes.name: Microtubule
nodes.description: Subcellular cytoskeletal structures that may encode basic rules giving rise to cognitive functions.

nodes.name: Xenobot
nodes.description: Proto-organisms created from re-arranged non-neural tissues (specifically Xenopus) that display novel morphologic and behavioral competencies.

nodes.name: Electrophysiology
nodes.description: A technique to measure electrical properties of biological cells and tissues.

nodes.name: Tissue Engineering
nodes.description: The use of a combination of cells, engineering, and materials methods to improve or replace biological tissues, or create novel constructs.

nodes.name: Behavior
nodes.description: Observable response patterns or motor outputs used to infer mental states.

nodes.name: Phospholipid Membrane
nodes.description: The membrane structure of cells that may be involved in encoding cognitive rules.

nodes.name: Inverse Drug Screen
nodes.description: A systematic hierarchical drug screening strategy using known pharmacological compounds to implicate specific molecular candidates in a biological phenomenon.

nodes.name: K_ATP Channel
nodes.description: ATP-sensitive potassium channel implicated in embryonic left-right patterning.

nodes.name: Calcicludine
nodes.description: A drug that blocks all calcium channels, used in hierarchical screens.

nodes.name: omega-conotoxin MVIIC
nodes.description: A toxin that blocks P/Q and N-type calcium channels.

nodes.name: Tributyl Tin
nodes.description: A chloride/hydroxide exchanger inhibitor used in chloride transport screens.

nodes.name: Gallus gallus
nodes.description: Chick embryo model system used for imaging and developmental studies.

nodes.name: Calcium Channel
nodes.description: A family of ion channels permeable to calcium ions.

nodes.name: Chloride Transport
nodes.description: The movement of chloride ions across membranes, screened using TBT and other blockers.

nodes.name: Octopus bimaculoides
nodes.description: A species of octopus inhabiting the Pacific Ocean, known as the California two-spot octopus, used as a model organism for camouflage studies.

nodes.name: Chromatophore
nodes.description: Highly specialized chromatic elements in the skin responsible for generating color through pigmentation (yellow, red, brown).

nodes.name: Iridophore
nodes.description: Chromatic elements that work as selective reflective filters due to 1D photonic stacks, reflecting colors from blue to red.

nodes.name: Leucophore
nodes.description: Chromatic elements that display a broadband scattering response due to disordered reflectin granules.

nodes.name: Radial Muscle
nodes.description: Muscles directly innervated to the brain that control the expansion or punctuation of the chromatophore sacculus.

nodes.name: Sacculus
nodes.description: An elastic sac within the chromatophore containing tethered pigment granules.

nodes.name: Reflectin
nodes.description: A protein found in iridophores and leucophores that creates index contrast for reflection or scattering.

nodes.name: Glutamate
nodes.description: A chemical agent used in this study (sodium L-glutamate) to stabilize skin and minimize muscular movement.

nodes.name: Silk Fibroin
nodes.description: A protein extracted from Bombyx mori cocoons used to stabilize excised octopus skin for optical analysis.

nodes.name: Multispectral Mapping
nodes.description: A spectral imaging technique collecting 3D optical image cubes to identify spatial distribution and spectral response of chromatic elements.

nodes.name: Structural Coloration
nodes.description: Color generation through interference with visible light, primarily by iridophores.

nodes.name: Pigmentary Coloration
nodes.description: Color generation through selective absorption by pigments within chromatophores.

nodes.name: Camouflage
nodes.description: The ability of cephalopods to rapidly change body patterns to match surroundings.

nodes.name: iv
nodes.description: A gene (inverted viscerum) in mice where mutation causes randomization of left-right asymmetry.

nodes.name: Left-Right Dynein
nodes.description: A novel dynein heavy chain gene mutated in iv and lgl mice, expressed in the node.

nodes.name: Activin
nodes.description: A signaling molecule that may suppress the left-sided program initiated by Shh.

nodes.name: F Molecule
nodes.description: A hypothetical chiral molecule proposed to align the three cardinal body axes.

nodes.name: Dynein
nodes.description: Microtubule-based motor proteins involved in force production and transport.

nodes.name: Zic3
nodes.description: A gene encoding a zinc finger transcription factor, mutations in which cause X-linked situs abnormalities.

nodes.name: Lefty-1
nodes.description: A downstream gene encoding a TGFbeta family member involved in providing LR cues.

nodes.name: Control Flow
nodes.description: The system that activates or deploys available perception and action resources in a context-specific way, represented as switching between attractors or reference frames.

nodes.name: Multi-scale Entanglement Renormalization Ansatz
nodes.description: A specific tensor network architecture where every pair of lower-level operators is entangled at every hierarchical level, relevant for detecting entanglement.

nodes.name: Topological Quantum Neural Network
nodes.description: A general framework in which tensor networks as control systems can be implemented, related to TQFTs.

nodes.name: Quantum Coherence
nodes.description: A quantum mechanical property suggested to be used as a computational resource by prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells.

nodes.name: Calcium Ion
nodes.description: A second messenger used in signaling pathways and bowtie networks in eukaryotic cells.

nodes.name: Eukaryote
nodes.description: Organisms characterized by intracellular compartmentalization and morphological degrees of freedom, utilizing complex signaling pathways.

nodes.name: Prokaryote
nodes.description: Single-celled organisms with shallower control hierarchies primarily focused on metabolic adaptation and replication.

nodes.name: Interoception
nodes.description: The sense of the internal state of the body, generated by visceromotor cortical regions via inference.

nodes.name: Predictive Coding
nodes.description: A mechanism utilized in inference processes for homeostasis-allostasis to minimize free energy of internal state trajectories.

nodes.name: Bowtie Network
nodes.description: A network architecture with high fan-in/fan-out to/from multi-use proteins or second messengers, ubiquitous in higher eukaryotic cells.

nodes.name: Primitive Streak
nodes.description: Structure in the chick embryo where H+/K+-ATPase and Kir4.1 are expressed.

nodes.name: Connexin43
nodes.description: A gap junction protein expressed in a circumferential pattern around the early streak.

nodes.name: Latrunculin
nodes.description: A drug that disrupts actin filament organization.

nodes.name: Nocodazole
nodes.description: A drug that disrupts microtubule organization.

nodes.name: Kinesin
nodes.description: Motor proteins (including KHC) that move cargo along microtubules, showing directional bias in early embryos.

nodes.name: BioElectric Network
nodes.description: A minimal computational model constructed to simulate somatic computation in non-neural bioelectric networks.

nodes.name: Electrodiffusion
nodes.description: The process governing the flux of ions driven by both voltage gradients and concentration gradients.

nodes.name: Logic gate
nodes.description: Circuits that perform elementary logic operations like AND, OR, XOR, used as a benchmark for computation.

nodes.name: Sodium-potassium pump
nodes.description: An ion pump that actively maintains non-zero membrane potential.

nodes.name: Backpropagation through time
nodes.description: A gradient-based training method used to optimize the parameters of the recurrent bioelectric networks.

nodes.name: French flag pattern
nodes.description: A specific configuration of Vmem levels (bands of hyperpolarized, intermediate, and depolarized states) used to test pattern detection.

nodes.name: Voltage gating
nodes.description: A mechanism where the permeability of a gap junction is modulated by the Vmem of connected cells.

nodes.name: Principle of Unitarity
nodes.description: The fundamental axiom of quantum theory stating that observable information is neither created nor destroyed by physical processes.

nodes.name: Entanglement
nodes.description: A quantum phenomenon where the states of systems are coupled such that they cannot be described independently, linked here to the asymptotic limit of the FEP.

nodes.name: Separability
nodes.description: The absence of quantum entanglement between physical systems, allowing them to be distinguished as distinct entities.

nodes.name: Holographic Screen
nodes.description: A boundary that limits communication between separated regions to the bits encoded on it, implementing the Markov blanket in a quantum setting.

nodes.name: Symmetry Breaking
nodes.description: The process by which thermodynamic symmetries are broken, allowing for system identification and measurement.

nodes.name: Decoherence
nodes.description: The dissipation of quantum coherence, often induced by interaction or symmetry breaking, rendering states separable.

nodes.name: Quantum Contextuality
nodes.description: A nonclassical effect demonstrating the presence of entanglement between distinct physical degrees of freedom, induced by noncommutativity of QRFs.

nodes.name: Bacterium
nodes.description: A model organism mentioned as a nontrivial agent capable of active inference via chemotaxis.

nodes.name: Dendritic Spine
nodes.description: Small membranous protrusions on neurons mentioned as a scale at which QRF hierarchies are implemented.

nodes.name: Prediction Error
nodes.description: The difference between expected and actual sensory states; minimizing this is the goal of the FEP.

nodes.name: Intrinsically Motivated Goal Exploration Process
nodes.description: Curiosity-driven exploration algorithms adapted from AI to automatically discover the range of reachable goal states of GRNs.

nodes.name: Transcriptional Space
nodes.description: The state space of gene expression levels through which a GRN navigates.

nodes.name: Versatility
nodes.description: The capacity of a system to reach diverse goal states under different interventions.

nodes.name: Robustness
nodes.description: The ability of a system to reach a goal state despite various perturbations during traversal.

nodes.name: RKIP-ERK Pathway
nodes.description: A specific signaling pathway used as a case study, where specific states are associated with tumor development.

nodes.name: Embryogenesis
nodes.description: The process of embryo development, driven by gene regulatory networks.

nodes.name: RKIP
nodes.description: Raf kinase inhibitor protein, a component of the RKIP-ERK pathway.

nodes.name: ERK
nodes.description: Extracellular signal-regulated kinase, a component of the RKIP-ERK pathway.

nodes.name: ODE Model
nodes.description: Ordinary Differential Equation models used to simulate the dynamic interactions between nodes of the network.

nodes.name: Perturbation
nodes.description: Disturbances applied to the system to test robustness, including noise, pushes, and walls.

nodes.name: Cell-View Sorting Algorithm
nodes.description: A distributed version of sorting algorithms where state evaluations and move decisions are made from the local perspective of each cell rather than a top-down controller.

nodes.name: Traditional Sorting Algorithm
nodes.description: Conventional sorting algorithms where a single top-down controller implements a set of rules to move cells around.

nodes.name: Frozen Cell
nodes.description: A cell that does not always move even though the algorithm tells it to, representing a damaged or defective cell in the substrate.

nodes.name: Delayed Gratification
nodes.description: The ability to temporarily go further away from a goal (reduce sortedness) in order to achieve gains later in the process.

nodes.name: Algotype
nodes.description: The specific sorting algorithm (policy) a cell uses to dictate its movement, analogous to a fixed genetic or phenotypic identity.

nodes.name: Chimeric Array
nodes.description: An array in which different cells use different sorting policies (Algotypes) to achieve their objectives.

nodes.name: Aggregation Value
nodes.description: A metric of the degree to which the same type of cells cluster together spatially during the sorting process.

nodes.name: Sortedness
nodes.description: The percentage of cells that strictly follow the designated sort order, used to measure the progress of the sorting process.

nodes.name: Bubble Sort
nodes.description: A simple sorting algorithm that repeatedly steps through the list, compares adjacent elements and swaps them if they are in the wrong order.

nodes.name: Insertion Sort
nodes.description: A sorting algorithm that builds the final sorted array one item at a time.

nodes.name: Selection Sort
nodes.description: A sorting algorithm that divides the input list into two parts: the sublist of items already sorted and the sublist of items remaining to be sorted.

nodes.name: Monotonicity Error
nodes.description: The number of cells that violate the monotonic order of the array.

nodes.name: Animal Cap
nodes.description: A region of the developing frog embryo (ectoderm) that typically gives rise to epidermis and neural tissue.

nodes.name: Cardiac Tissue
nodes.description: Muscle tissue used in some biological robot designs to produce volumetric actuation.

nodes.name: AI-driven Design
nodes.description: The use of computational tools and evolutionary algorithms to simulate and optimize the morphology of biological robots before fabrication.

nodes.name: Kinematic Self-replication
nodes.description: A mode of reproduction where biological robots assemble loose cells in their environment into new copies of themselves.

nodes.name: Morphospace
nodes.description: The theoretical space of all possible anatomical shapes and configurations that a biological system can assume.

nodes.name: Agential Material
nodes.description: Materials composed of subunits (like living cells) that possess built-in competencies, agendas, and problem-solving capabilities.

nodes.name: Open-loop Control
nodes.description: A type of control system where the output has no influence or feedback on the control action, describing the movement of early xenobots.

nodes.name: Reaction-Diffusion
nodes.description: A mathematical framework proposed by Turing where chemical species react and diffuse to amplify small random concentration gradients into stable patterns.

nodes.name: Negative Feedback
nodes.description: A control mechanism used to achieve reliability by characterizing the existing body shape to create an error signal and adjust parameters.

nodes.name: Computation Wave
nodes.description: A chemical wave proposed in the model that travels through the tissue to count the number of peaks in a reaction-diffusion pattern.

nodes.name: Activator
nodes.description: The chemical species 'A' in a reaction-diffusion system that generates more of itself and the inhibitor.

nodes.name: Inhibitor
nodes.description: The chemical species 'I' in a reaction-diffusion system that reduces concentrations and diffuses faster than the activator.

nodes.name: BITSEY
nodes.description: A simulator based on BETSE used for simulating networks of cells with GRNs, reactions, and diffusion.

nodes.name: Expansion-Repression
nodes.description: A mechanism proposed by Barkai using an expander species to scale reaction-diffusion patterns to field length.

nodes.name: Segmentation Clock
nodes.description: A mechanism involving waves of gene expression that helps establish the segmental pattern of the vertebrate axis.

nodes.name: Intrinsic Wavelength
nodes.description: The characteristic length of a reaction-diffusion pattern, determined by diffusion and degradation constants.

nodes.name: Fibroblast Growth Factor
nodes.description: A molecule that affects embryo size and feeds forward to affect the intrinsic wavelength of RD patterns in mice.

nodes.name: Mytilus galloprovincialis
nodes.description: The Mediterranean mussel or blue mussel, the subject of the cryopreservation study.

nodes.name: Cryopreservation
nodes.description: A process where organelles, cells, tissues, extracellular matrix, organs, or any other biological constructs susceptible to damage caused by unregulated chemical kinetics are preserved by cooling to very low temperatures.

nodes.name: Ethylene Glycol
nodes.description: A permeable cryoprotectant agent (CPA) used in the study for larval preservation.

nodes.name: Trehalose
nodes.description: A non-permeable sugar used as a cryoprotectant to diminish osmotic shock.

nodes.name: Polyvinylpyrrolidone
nodes.description: A polymer used as a cryoprotectant, found to cause abnormalities at high concentrations in this study.

nodes.name: Trochophore Larva
nodes.description: An early free-swimming planktonic marine larva with several bands of cilia.

nodes.name: D-larva
nodes.description: The early veliger larval stage of the mussel, characterized by a D-shaped shell.

nodes.name: Pediveliger Larva
nodes.description: The larval stage competent for settlement, possessing both a velum and a foot.

nodes.name: Osmotic Shock
nodes.description: Sudden change in solute concentration around a cell, which non-permeable CPAs like Trehalose help to diminish.

nodes.name: Membrane Permeability
nodes.description: The rate of passive diffusion of molecules through the membrane, noted as a factor for future research in cryopreservation optimization.

nodes.name: Settlement
nodes.description: The process where the larvae attach to a substrate and metamorphose into the juvenile stage (spat).

nodes.name: Shell Length
nodes.description: A metric used to measure larval growth and development.

nodes.name: Dendritic Remodeling
nodes.description: Activity-dependent structural changes in dendrites, including alterations of spine location, density, and function.

nodes.name: Trophic Reward
nodes.description: Metabolic maintenance or resources provided to functional biological units (like dendritic branches) based on their activity or informativeness.

nodes.name: Quantum State Tomography
nodes.description: A process of reconstructing the quantum state of a system, used here as a model for how neurons integrate inputs.

nodes.name: Cone-Cocone Diagram
nodes.description: A mathematical structure representing networks of classifiers with limits and colimits, used to model hierarchical Bayesian inference.

nodes.name: CheY-P
nodes.description: Phosphorylated form of CheY protein in bacteria, acting as a simple QRF for chemotaxis.

nodes.name: Trans-epithelial Potential
nodes.description: A voltage gradient that forms at the outer boundary of an organ or organism, implicated in development and wound healing.

nodes.name: Maxwell Capacitance Matrix
nodes.description: A mathematical formulation used in BETSE to calculate voltages in biological tissue by treating cell interfaces as capacitive systems.

nodes.name: Wound Healing
nodes.description: The process of repairing tissue injury, which involves endogenous electric fields.

nodes.name: Guided self-assembly
nodes.description: A process where multicellular dynamics are guided towards desired structures, functions, and computational capacity.

nodes.name: Skin cell
nodes.description: Wild-type cells from Xenopus laevis used to construct xenobots.

nodes.name: Cardiac cell
nodes.description: Wild-type cells from Xenopus laevis used to construct xenobots, likely providing motility.

nodes.name: Low Frequency Vibration
nodes.description: Mechanical vibrations in the low frequency range (e.g., <200 Hz) acting as an environmental pollutant or experimental perturbation.

nodes.name: Tail Morphogenesis
nodes.description: The developmental process of forming the tail structure.

nodes.name: Cytoplasmic Dynamics
nodes.description: Movement of intracellular components, potentially via standing waves induced by vibration.

nodes.name: Isomerism
nodes.description: Loss of left-right asymmetry resulting in symmetry of organs (e.g., centrally placed pancreas).

nodes.name: 15 Hz Vibration
nodes.description: Specific frequency of vibration tested, noted for inducing neural tube defects.

nodes.name: 100 Hz Vibration
nodes.description: Specific frequency of vibration tested.

nodes.name: Horizontal Vibration
nodes.description: Vibration applied perpendicular to gravity.

nodes.name: Vertical Vibration
nodes.description: Vibration applied parallel to gravity.

nodes.name: Bent Tail
nodes.description: Abnormal tail morphology characterized by distinct bends or kinks.

nodes.name: Biotin Permeability Assay
nodes.description: A method used to test the integrity of the epithelial barrier/tight junctions.

nodes.name: HDAC activity
nodes.description: Enzymatic activity of histone deacetylases that removes acetyl groups from histones, leading to chromatin repression.

nodes.name: HDAC1
nodes.description: Class I histone deacetylase expressed in the mesenchymal cells of the regeneration bud during the first 2 days of regeneration.

nodes.name: HDAC6
nodes.description: Class II histone deacetylase whose expression is absent in the regeneration bud at 24 and 48 hpa.

nodes.name: Sin3
nodes.description: Co-factor protein that mediates the interaction between Mad3 and HDAC complexes.

nodes.name: Trichostatin A
nodes.description: Specific and potent chemical inhibitor of Class I and Class II HDACs.

nodes.name: Histone acetylation
nodes.description: Post-translational modification of histone tails that generally correlates with gene transcription; modulated by HDACs.

nodes.name: BMP2
nodes.description: Gene required for promoting tail outgrowth; expression is altered by HDAC inhibition.

nodes.name: Notch1
nodes.description: Gene expressed in the neural ampulla of the regeneration bud, required for tail regeneration.

nodes.name: TRPN1
nodes.description: A transient receptor potential (TRP) channel, also known as NOMPC, characterized by 29 ankyrin repeats (28 in Xenopus) at its intracellular N terminus.

nodes.name: TRPA1
nodes.description: A TRP channel candidate for the transduction channel in vertebrate hair cells, formerly known as ANKTM1.

nodes.name: Hair Cell
nodes.description: Sensory cells in the inner ear and lateral line responsible for transducing sound and balance.

nodes.name: Kinocilium
nodes.description: A true cilium containing a (9 + 2) arrangement of microtubules found on the apical surface of hair cells.

nodes.name: Stereocilia
nodes.description: Microscopically fine projections containing actin filaments on the apical surface of hair cells, grouped in bundles.

nodes.name: Mechanotransduction
nodes.description: The process by which mechanical forces are converted into electrical signals (depolarization) in hair cells.

nodes.name: FM1-43
nodes.description: A small fluorescent dye that passes through open transduction channels, used to detect functional hair cells.

nodes.name: Neomycin
nodes.description: An aminoglycoside antibiotic that specifically destroys hair cells.

nodes.name: Calcium Chelator
nodes.description: Chemicals like EGTA and BAPTA that bind calcium ions, used to disrupt transduction apparatus and kinocilial links.

nodes.name: Cadherin 23
nodes.description: A protein identified as a component of kinocilial links and tip links.

nodes.name: Ciliated Epidermal Cell
nodes.description: Cells distributed over the surface of the embryo containing motile cilia.

nodes.name: Intraflagellar Transport
nodes.description: A specialized transport system for the assembly and maintenance of cilia.

nodes.name: Macrophage Polarization
nodes.description: The development of a specific macrophage phenotype (M1 or M2) in response to local environmental cues.

nodes.name: K ATP Channel
nodes.description: ATP-sensitive potassium channels composed of pore-forming Kir6.x subunits and regulatory SUR subunits.

nodes.name: Pinacidil
nodes.description: A drug that acts as a specific opener of K ATP channels.

nodes.name: M1 Macrophage
nodes.description: Classically activated macrophages that secrete inflammatory cytokines and degrade extracellular matrix.

nodes.name: M2 Macrophage
nodes.description: Alternatively activated macrophages involved in wound healing, fibrosis, and immunosuppression.

nodes.name: THP-1
nodes.description: A human monocytic cell line used as a model for macrophage polarization.

nodes.name: TNF-alpha
nodes.description: A pro-inflammatory cytokine and marker for M1 macrophage polarization.

nodes.name: CD206
nodes.description: A mannose receptor used as a marker for M2 macrophage polarization.

nodes.name: Kir6.2
nodes.description: A pore-forming subunit of the K ATP channel found mainly in plasma membranes.

nodes.name: SUR1
nodes.description: A regulatory sulfonylurea receptor subunit of the K ATP channel.

nodes.name: Bacterial Biofilm
nodes.description: Communities of bacteria that exhibit collective behaviors and bioelectric coordination similar to multicellular tissues.

nodes.name: Cellular Energy Budget
nodes.description: The total metabolic power consumption available to a cell to maintain its state and perform functions.

nodes.name: Classical Information Processing

nodes.name: Sister Cell

nodes.name: Evolutionary Transitions in Individuality
nodes.description: The process where individuals at a lower level of organization work together to create a new organismic entity and evolutionary unit at a higher level.

nodes.name: Evolutionary Connectionism
nodes.description: A theoretical framework translating distributed learning principles from neural networks into the domain of natural selection to explain the organization of relationships among evolutionary units.

nodes.description: A computational function where the output cannot be decomposed into a sum of sub-functions over individual inputs, requiring context-sensitive interactions (e.g., XOR).

nodes.name: Hebbian Learning
nodes.description: A simple unsupervised learning principle where connections are adjusted based on the correlation of activity between nodes.

nodes.name: Information Integration
nodes.description: The capability of a system to combine information from multiple sources to produce a coordinated response.

nodes.name: Collective Action
